column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=The coalescence of black holes is one of the most important sources of gravitational waves .
#Text=A gravitational wave occurs owing to a variation in the gravitational field , such as the motion of massive bodies .

#Text=Although a gravitational wave can commonly occur owing to a small variation in the gravitational field , the magnitude of the gravitational wave in such a variation is too small to detect at our observable accuracy .
#Text=Hence , an observable gravitational wave needs a sufficient magnitude so that it can be detected at observatories such as the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory ( LIGO ) .
#Text=Since the magnitude of a gravitational wave becomes large along with the mass of its source , the candidate sources of detectable gravitational waves should be massive .
#Text=Thus , the coalescence of black holes can be a source that releases a gravitational wave that is sufficiently large to be detected at the LIGO .
#Text=Nowadays , several gravitational waves are detected at observatories .
#Text=Most of their sources are the binary black hole mergers in GW150914 , GW151226 , GW170104 , GW170608 , GW170814 .
#Text=Thus , the coalescence of black holes can be a frequently detectable source of gravitational waves .

#Text=Further , a system of binary black holes has three angular momenta — two spin angular momenta of the black holes and one orbital angular momentum — and these angular momenta play important roles in the analysis of the system .

#Text=Note that the angular momenta for a binary black hole merger are described by the primary spin parameter , secondary spin parameter and orbital angular momentum in the initial state , and the spin parameter in the final state .
#Text=Black holes have conserved quantities such as mass and angular momentum .
#Text=Two types of energies are included in the mass of the black hole : a reducible energy and an irreducible mass .
#Text=The roles of these two energies can be clarified in consideration of particle absorption to vary the black hole .
#Text=In particle absorption , the variations in the mass and angular momentum of a black hole can be related to a particle ’s momenta such as the radial and angular momenta .

#Text=Here , the black hole ’s angular momentum can be reduced by our choice of the particle ’s angular momentum ; thus , part of the particle ’s angular momentum is a reducible energy in the variation of the black hole ’s mass .
#Text=Interestingly , the remaining part cannot be reduced with any choice of the particle ’s momenta ; therefore , the remaining part is called the irreducible mass of a black hole .
#Text=This irreducible mass can be understood as the surface energy of the black hole .
#Text=For example , even if the mass of a black hole decreases during particle absorption , the irreducible mass still increases .
#Text=Since this behavior of the irreducible mass is very similar to the entropy in thermodynamics , its square — the area of the horizon — is related to the Bekenstein – Hawking entropy .
#Text=Further , the black hole can emit energy away from its horizon according to a quantum process .
#Text=Owing to this small portion of the energy , the black hole can be assumed to be a thermal object having the Hawking temperature accounted from the emission .
#Text=For the variation in the black hole ’s mass , the Bekenstein – Hawking entropy and Hawking temperature act as thermodynamic variables in the first law of thermodynamics .
#Text=In addition , the Bekenstein – Hawking entropy increases in an irreversible process in the second law of thermodynamics according to the behavior of the irreducible mass .
#Text=Thus , the black hole itself can be considered as a thermal system obeying the laws of thermodynamics .
